content.text: Sometimes users don't have a specific query. They want to explore. Browsing models formalize this exploration.
content.hook: Search is teletransportation; Browsing is walking.

outcomes: Flat Browsing: Linear scanning (e.g., reading a list).
Structure-Guided Browsing: Hierarchical navigation (e.g., File Explorer).
Hypertext Browsing: Networked navigation (e.g., The Web).

slides.title: The Hypertext Model
items: Anchors: The clickable area leading to a link.
Maps/History: Tools to prevent 'getting lost in hyperspace'.

content.description: Logic of navigating a networked information space.

content.definition: A model by Marcia Bates. Users don't just run one query. They run a query, read a bit, learn a new term, run a new query, and 'pick berries' (info) along the way.
content.text: This contrasts with the standard 'Match-Rank-Retrieve' model.

content.description: Design a browsing interface for a Music Library. How do you allow a user to drift from 'Bach' to 'Baroque' to '17th Century History' without a search bar?

content.process: Fetch page, extract all <a href> links, add to queue.
content.output: A printed list of visited titles (Breadcrumbs).

slides.title: Quiz
questions: How does the Berry-Picking model differ from the classic Water-fall retrieval model?
What is the role of a 'Sitemap' in structure-guided browsing?
Give an example of a dynamic taxonomy.
answers: A phenomenon where users lose their orientation or "sense of place" within a large, complex, nonlinear hypertext structure.
The classic model assumes a single static query -> final output. Berry-picking assumes the user's query and information need evolve dynamically as they find and read partial information.
It provides a hierarchical overview (map) of the entire site's structure, allowing users to jump to specific sections without sequential clicking.
Faceted search on Amazon (filtering by Brand, Price, Rating) where the categories displayed depend on the current search results.
